values.description:
While working on adding sdf version 1.7, I noticed that the Converter only removed the first element it found specified by the `<remove>` tag, so I've changed it to remove all of them and included a test.

I also added an extra expectation when converter loads something already at the desired end version that it doesn't modify the xml document.
values.title: Converter: remove all matching elements specified by `<remove>` tag

values.description:
This is a backport of pull request #542, which accompanied [homebrew-simulation pull request 666](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/666), which added an `ignition-tools` dependency to sdformat7. This pull request accompanies [homebrew-simulation PR 810](https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/pull/810) which adds that dependency to sdformat6.

The `sdf6` branch is unstable when built against that homebrew-simulation pull request with one of the ign tests failing:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64&build=599)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/sdformat/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/599/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/sdformat/job/sdformat-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/599/

values.description:
It is stated numerous times in the SDF Specification files that name attributes must be unique within a certain scope. This formalizes the requirement to state that if an element's name is given by the value of its name attribute, sibling elements of the same type must have unique names. This adds a check to this effect in `ign sdf --check` and adds several helper functions to the `sdf::Element` class to support the check.

* `Element::CountNamedElements(std::string)` to aid in checking for unique names

* `Element::HasUniqueChildNames()` that uses `CountNamedElements()` to determine if there are any duplicate name attribute values among child elements

* `GetElementTypeNames()` that returns a set of the type names of all the child elements

I placed the `recursiveSameTypeUniqueNames()` function inside `ign.cc`; it can be moved to the Element class if we want to make it a part of the public API.

I noticed some issues in the SDF spec documentation too that could be cleaned up, but I haven't addressed in this pull request:

* [sensor name attribute](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=sensor#sensor_name): "This name must not match another model in the model." (model in the model -> sensor in the parent link)
* [joint name attribute](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=joint#joint_name): "A unique name for the joint within the scope of the model." (scope of the model -> scope of the parent link)

EDIT: fixes #216
values.title: Use "ign sdf --check" to check sibling elements of the same type for non-unique names

values.description:
tl;dr

Support using paths relative to the SDF file within:

* `<mesh><uri>`
* `<actor><skin><filename>`
* `<actor><animation><filename>` 

That is, for this file tree:

```
some_model/
├── meshes
│   └── some_mesh.dae
├── model.config
└── model.sdf
```

`model.sdf` may reference the mesh as follows:

```
                <geometry>
                    <mesh>
                        <uri>meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>
                    </mesh>
                </geometry>
```

## Alternatives

On Gazebo classic, it would usually have been like this:

```
                <geometry>
                    <mesh>
                        <uri>model://some_model/meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>
                    </mesh>
                </geometry>
```

Where `model://` would get substituted by paths in the user's `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` until a valid file was found.

As we move to models hosted on Ignition Fuel, just the model name becomes insufficient to fully identify a model, so we need better ways of referring to resources.

Some alternatives considered:

* `https://`

    * Status:
    
        * Partial support on Gazebo 9
        * Supported within `<include><uri>` on Ignition
        
    * Pros:
    
        * No ambiguity
        
    * Cons:
    
        * Full URL must be known while creating model. When referring to resources belonging to the same model, it's a chicken and egg problem: how to know the resource URL before uploading the model to the site?
        * Tied to an online service
        
    
* Absolute path \(`file:///`, `/`\)

    * Status:
    
        * Supported both on Gazebo 9 and Ignition
        
    * Pros:
    
        * No ambiguity
        
    * Cons:
    
        * Not easily portable from one computer to another
        * Exposes creator's username \(`/home/username/...`\)
        
    
* `model://`

    * Status:
    
        * Full support on Gazebo 9
        * Partial support for meshes on Ignition. Gets converted to absolute path after downloaded from Fuel.
        
    * Pros:
    
        * Portable
        
    * Cons:
    
        * Ambiguous, no owner / host site info
        
    
* Relative path `meshes/`

    * Status:
    
        * Support added on this PR, to be used by Ignition
        
    * Pros:
    
        * No ambiguity
        * Portable
        
    * Cons:
    
        * Hard to share resources across models
        
    

Given that all alternatives have pros and cons, there isn't one right answer, so we need to support multiple approaches. This pull request adds support for relative paths without breaking any of the previous use cases \*\*. We should still address its "con", which is the difficulty of sharing resources across models. But that isn't supported at all on Ignition yet, so I think it can be considered out of the scope of this PR.

It's also worth mentioning that we've already been using relative paths inside `DAE` and `OBJ` files for a while, so it's only natural to extend it to SDF.

\*\* Except for relative paths to the directory `ign gazebo` is called from, which I don't think is a common case.

## Try it out

You'll need [this](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/433/handle-relative-uris/diff) `ign-gazebo` PR.

Launch `ign gazebo`:

`ign gazebo -v 3`

Spawn an example model with relative paths that I uploaded to Fuel:

```
ign service -s /world/default/create \
--reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory \
--reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean \
--timeout 5000 \
--req 'sdf: '\
'"<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>'\
'<sdf version=\"1.6\">'\
'<include>'\
'<uri>https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/chapulina/models/X1 Config 1 - relative paths</uri>'\
'</include>'\
'</sdf>" '\
'pose: {position: {z: 1}} '\
'name: "vehicle" '\
'allow_renaming: true'
```

See that all meshes are properly loaded.

To try actors, you'll need [this ign-gazebo PR](https://bitbucket.org/mingfeisun/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/4/support-spawning-actors-at-runtime/diff), and you can spawn an actor with relative paths like this (world must use ogre 1):

```
ign service -s /world/actors/create \
--reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory \
--reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean \
--timeout 5000 \
--req 'sdf: '\
'"<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>'\
'<sdf version=\"1.6\">'\
'<include>'\
'<uri>https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/chapulina/models/actor - relative paths</uri>'\
'</include>'\
'</sdf>" '\
'pose: {position: {z: 1}} '\
'name: "person" '\
'allow_renaming: true'
```

## Questions

* ~~With the current implementation, `mesh->Element()->Get<std::string>("uri")` will be different from `mesh->Uri()`. Is it better to also change the `uri` within the element to keep them consistent?~~ Now `Uri()` is the same as the raw `<uri>`
* ~~It could be argued that SDFormat shouldn't be changing the URI value and instead just reading it and passing it along. I'm fine with that, but for downstream applications that can't rely on `mesh->Element()` \(because the mesh object is serialized\), we'd need to add things like `Mesh::FilePath`, a `filepath` field to the equivalent ign-msg, etc, which break ABI. \(ok, this is not a question, more like a disclaimer :grimacing: \)~~ Now SDF is only storing `FilePath` and `ign-gazebo` is combining them before populating the message.
values.title: Accept relative path in <uri>

tl;dr

Support using paths relative to the SDF file within:

  • <mesh><uri>
  • <actor><skin><filename>
  • <actor><animation><filename>

That is, for this file tree:

some_model/
├── meshes
│   └── some_mesh.dae
├── model.config
└── model.sdf

                <geometry>
                    <mesh>
                        <uri>meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>
                    </mesh>

On Gazebo classic, it would usually have been like this:

                <geometry>
                    <mesh>
                        <uri>model://some_model/meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>

Where model:// would get substituted by paths in the user's GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH until a valid file was found.

As we move to models hosted on Ignition Fuel, just the model name becomes insufficient to fully identify a model, so we need better ways of referring to resources.

Some alternatives considered:

  • https://

    • Status:

      • Partial support on Gazebo 9
      • Supported within <include><uri> on Ignition

    • Pros:

      • No ambiguity

    • Cons:

      • Full URL must be known while creating model. When referring to resources belonging to the same model, it's a chicken and egg problem: how to know the resource URL before uploading the model to the site?
      • Tied to an online service

  • Absolute path (file:///, /)

    • Status:

      • Supported both on Gazebo 9 and Ignition

    • Pros:

      • No ambiguity

    • Cons:

      • Not easily portable from one computer to another
      • Exposes creator's username (/home/username/...)

  • model://

    • Status:

      • Full support on Gazebo 9
      • Partial support for meshes on Ignition. Gets converted to absolute path after downloaded from Fuel.

    • Pros:

      • Portable

    • Cons:

      • Ambiguous, no owner / host site info

  • Relative path meshes/

    • Status:

      • Support added on this PR, to be used by Ignition

    • Pros:

      • No ambiguity
      • Portable

    • Cons:

      • Hard to share resources across models

Given that all alternatives have pros and cons, there isn't one right answer, so we need to support multiple approaches. This pull request adds support for relative paths without breaking any of the previous use cases **. We should still address its "con", which is the difficulty of sharing resources across models. But that isn't supported at all on Ignition yet, so I think it can be considered out of the scope of this PR.

It's also worth mentioning that we've already been using relative paths inside DAE and OBJ files for a while, so it's only natural to extend it to SDF.

** Except for relative paths to the directory ign gazebo is called from, which I don't think is a common case.

Try it out

You'll need this ign-gazebo PR.

Launch ign gazebo:

ign gazebo -v 3

Spawn an example model with relative paths that I uploaded to Fuel:

ign service -s /world/default/create \
--reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory \
--reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean \
--timeout 5000 \
--req 'sdf: '\
'"<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>'\
'<sdf version=\"1.6\">'\
'<include>'\
'<uri>https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/chapulina/models/X1 Config 1 - relative paths</uri>'\
'</include>'\
'</sdf>" '\

To try actors, you'll need this ign-gazebo PR, and you can spawn an actor with relative paths like this (world must use ogre 1):

--reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory \
--reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean \
--timeout 5000 \
--req 'sdf: '\
'"<?xml version=\"1.0\" ?>'\
'<sdf version=\"1.6\">'\
'<include>'\
'<uri>https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/chapulina/models/actor - relative paths</uri>'\
'</include>'\
'</sdf>" '\
'pose: {position: {z: 1}} '\
'name: "person" '\
'allow_renaming: true'

Questions

  • With the current implementation, mesh->Element()->Get<std::string>("uri") will be different from mesh->Uri(). Is it better to also change the uri within the element to keep them consistent? Now Uri() is the same as the raw <uri>
  • It could be argued that SDFormat shouldn't be changing the URI value and instead just reading it and passing it along. I'm fine with that, but for downstream applications that can't rely on mesh->Element() (because the mesh object is serialized), we'd need to add things like Mesh::FilePath, a filepath field to the equivalent ign-msg, etc, which break ABI. (ok, this is not a question, more like a disclaimer ) Now SDF is only storing FilePath and ign-gazebo is combining them before populating the message.

values.description:
Currently when you write an sdf file to a string, it inserts optional attributes with default values everywhere, even if they are not set (see [prius_hybrid_sensors](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/prius_hybrid_sensors/model.sdf#lines-33) from gazebo_models for example). This can be prevented by checking whether an attribute has been set before printing it.

I had to adjust some tests to expect the new behavior.
values.title: Element: don't print unset attributes

values.description:
When converting an sdf 1.4 file to sdf 1.5, a `use_parent_model_frame` tag is added to any `<axis>` elements. As of sdf7, when converting from 1.4 to 1.6, it adds multiple `use_parent_model_frame` tags. This can be seen by observing the console output of the `INTEGRATION_joint_axis_frame` test:

from [sdf6](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat6-homebrew-amd64/17/console):

~~~
19: [ RUN      ] JointAxisFrame.Version_1_4_missing
19: <axis>
19:   <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
19:   <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
19:   <limit>
19:     <lower>-1e+16</lower>
19:     <upper>1e+16</upper>
19:   </limit>
19: </axis>
19: [       OK ] JointAxisFrame.Version_1_4_missing (76 ms)
~~~

from [sdf8](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/sdformat-ci-sdformat8-homebrew-amd64/37/consoleFull) (sdf7 doesn't have dedicated CI jobs):

~~~
27: [ RUN      ] JointAxisFrame.Version_1_4_missing
27: <axis>
27:   <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
27:   <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
27:   <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
27:   <limit>
27:     <lower>-1e+16</lower>
27:     <upper>1e+16</upper>
27:   </limit>
27: </axis>
27: [       OK ] JointAxisFrame.Version_1_4_missing (53 ms)
~~~

I've added a test to expect that only 1 tag is added, and fixed the problem in Converter.cc by ensuring that a new `TiXmlDocument` object is used for each conversion, as currently the convert documents are appended.
values.title: Prevent duplicate `use_parent_model_frame` tags during file conversion

values.description:
PR #571 made `ToString` not print unset values. 
When converting between versions of sdf, the converter may add an element with a required attribute, but the added attribute is not considered "set". When using `ToString` on the parsed object, this attribute will not be printed. Trying to parse the output of `ToString` will fail because there is now a missing value on a required attribute.


For example, when the following snippet gets parsed, it gets upconverted into sdf 1.6.

```
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
  </world>
</sdf>
```

One element that gets added during this conversion is `<atmosphere>` which has a required attribute `type`. Here's the output of `ToString`:
```
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.6'>
  <world name='default'>
    <gravity>0 0 -9.8</gravity>
    <magnetic_field>6e-06 2.3e-05 -4.2e-05</magnetic_field>
    <atmosphere/>
    <physics>
      <max_step_size>0.001</max_step_size>
      <real_time_factor>1</real_time_factor>
      <real_time_update_rate>1000</real_time_update_rate>
    </physics>
    <scene>
      <ambient>0.4 0.4 0.4 1</ambient>
      <background>0.7 0.7 0.7 1</background>
      <shadows>1</shadows>
    </scene>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
Parsing this in will fail because `<atmosphere>` is missing its `type` attribute.


This PR also ensures that that clones of `sdf::Element` have identical outputs from calling `ToString`.
values.title: Fix ToString on required attributes and cloned elements

values.description:
While updating osrf/gazebo to use ignition citadel dependencies, we ran into some weird issues with namespace conflicts. I ended up isolating them in a branch:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/branch/avoid_some_using_namespace#diff

but I think I just found the source of the problem: a `using namespace ignition;` statement in an sdf header file. This PR removes it, and I think we should try to avoid `using namespace` statements in header files since it can affect lots of downstream code.
values.title: Lidar.hh: remove 'using namespace ignition'

values.description:
Part of the [SDF frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#replace-joint-axis-use_parent_model_frame-with-joint-axis-xyz-expressed_in) is replacing the `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` element with an attribute `//axis/@expressed_in`. The migration script should map `//axis[use_parent_model_frame='true'` to `//axis[@expressed_in='__model__'`, but there are no mechanisms in the `sdf::Converter` class to support this. So this pull request adds the `Converter::Map` function that reads `<map>` elements that specifies a map of fixed input values to fixed output values.

For example, a portion of the `<convert>` specification for the `//use_parent_model_frame` migration is as follows:

~~~
<convert name="model">
  <convert name="joint">
    <convert name="axis">
      <map>
        <from name="use_parent_model_frame">
          <value>true</value>
          <value>True</value>
          <value>TRUE</value>
          <value>1</value>
        </from>
        <to name="xyz/@expressed_in">
          <value>__model__</value>
        </to>
      </map>
      <remove element="use_parent_model_frame"/>
    </convert>
  </convert>
</convert>
~~~

The `//convert/map/from` element has a `@name` attribute that specifies the name of the source to convert from. The name is a little like XPATH, with `/` as a delimiter between parent and child elements, and `@` indicating an attribute. The `//from/value` elements specify input values that will trigger an output value to be created.

The `//convert/map/to` element also has a `@name` attribute that specifies the destination of the map operation, with the same interpretation of `/` and `@`. The `//to/value` elements specify output values corresponding to a `//from/value` input.

If there are an equal number of `//from/value` and `//to/value` elements, then the map is constructed with the `//from/value` mapped to `//to/value` based on the order they are specified (1st with 1st, 2nd with 2nd, etc).

If there are fewer `//from/value` elements than `//to/value` elements, then the excess `//to/value` elements are ignored, and the matching `//to/value` elements are mapped 1:1 with the available `//from/value` elements.

If there are more `//from/value` elements than `//to/value` elements, then the excess `//from/value` elements are mapped to the last `//to/value` element. This is the case for the `//use_parent_model_frame` example above in which all 4 `//from` values are mapped to a single `//to` value.

UPDATE: re-targeted to default.
values.title: Converter: add `<map>` element for converting fixed values

Part of the [SDF frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#replace-joint-axis-use_parent_model_frame-with-joint-axis-xyz-expressed_in) is replacing the `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` element with an attribute `//axis/@expressed_in`. The migration script should map `//axis[use_parent_model_frame='true'` to `//axis[@expressed_in='__model__'`, but there are no mechanisms in the `sdf::Converter` class to support this. So this pull request adds the `Converter::Map` function that reads `<map>` elements that specifies a map of fixed input values to fixed output values.

For example, a portion of the `<convert>` specification for the `//use_parent_model_frame` migration is as follows:

~~~
<convert name="model">
  <convert name="joint">
    <convert name="axis">
      <map>
        <from name="use_parent_model_frame">
          <value>true</value>
          <value>True</value>
          <value>TRUE</value>
          <value>1</value>
        </from>
        <to name="xyz/@expressed_in">
          <value>__model__</value>
        </to>
      </map>
      <remove element="use_parent_model_frame"/>
    </convert>
  </convert>
</convert>
~~~

The `//convert/map/from` element has a `@name` attribute that specifies the name of the source to convert from. The name is a little like XPATH, with `/` as a delimiter between parent and child elements, and `@` indicating an attribute. The `//from/value` elements specify input values that will trigger an output value to be created.

The `//convert/map/to` element also has a `@name` attribute that specifies the destination of the map operation, with the same interpretation of `/` and `@`. The `//to/value` elements specify output values corresponding to a `//from/value` input.

If there are an equal number of `//from/value` and `//to/value` elements, then the map is constructed with the `//from/value` mapped to `//to/value` based on the order they are specified (1st with 1st, 2nd with 2nd, etc).

If there are fewer `//from/value` elements than `//to/value` elements, then the excess `//to/value` elements are ignored, and the matching `//to/value` elements are mapped 1:1 with the available `//from/value` elements.

If there are more `//from/value` elements than `//to/value` elements, then the excess `//from/value` elements are mapped to the last `//to/value` element. This is the case for the `//use_parent_model_frame` example above in which all 4 `//from` values are mapped to a single `//to` value.

UPDATE: re-targeted to default.

values.description:
This was causing problems when loading actors like this:

## world_path/world.sdf

```
<include>
  <uri>actor_path</uri>
</include>
```

## actor_path/model.sdf

```
<uri>skin.dae</uri>
```

The skin path would be `world_path/skin.dae` instead of `actor_path/skin.dae`.

So this PR makes it so the parent path is only used if the element doesn't have a valid path yet.
values.title: Don't override path with parent path

values.description:
I noticed a weird issue in Converter when converting across multiple versions (ie. 1.4 -> 1.5 -> 1.6). It can manifest as multiple `use_parent_model_frame` elements being added, which was fixed in pull request #573. (I actually forgot about that PR, but just merged it into this one). I've since noticed another manifestation while trying to update gazebo11 to use citadel dependencies. It seems that when converting a sdf 1.4 world file that has gravity defined in the `//world/physics/gravity` element with a non-default value, it does not get moved to the `//world/gravity` element. It will instead have gravity elements under both physics and world, but with different values. I've updated an existing test in `INTEGRATION_converter` to use non-default values of gravity and to test conversion from 1.4 in addition to 1.5.

The fix is to change the scope of an `xmlDoc` variable so that the `*.convert` files are not appended to each other during conversion.
values.title: Converter: fix bug when converting across multiple versions

values.description:
This pull request builds on both ~~pull request #588~~ and ~~pull request #580~~. It is targeted at `spec_1.7_9` (pr #588) and currently includes the changes to the Converter from pr #580. Once those PR's are merged, this will be simply targeted at default.

This replaces the `//axis/use_parent_model_frame` boolean elements with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` string elements that store the name of a frame in which the joint axis is expressed. During conversion from sdf 1.6 -> 1.7, any `use_parent_model_frame` element with a true value is mapped to an `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute with value `__model__`, corresponding to the name of the model frame in the [sdf frame semantics proposal](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#7-replace-joint-axis-use_parent_model_frame-with-joint-axis-xyz-expressed_in).

It adds new API's to the `sdf::JointAxis` class and deprecates the API's related to `use_parent_model_frame`.

After some experimenting with xml stylesheets, I decided to include an `xslt` that is equivalent to the `1_6.convert` file. It is provided for reference but is not used by libsdformat or tested by the built-in tests.

I also made some minor formatting adjustments to the migration guide.
values.title: [Citadel] Replace `use_parent_model_frame` element with `//axis/xyz/@expressed_in` attribute in sdf 1.7

This pull request builds on both pull request #588 and pull request #580. It is targeted at spec_1.7_9 (pr #588) and currently includes the changes to the Converter from pr #580. Once those PR's are merged, this will be simply targeted at default.

This replaces the //axis/use_parent_model_frame boolean elements with //axis/xyz/@expressed_in string elements that store the name of a frame in which the joint axis is expressed. During conversion from sdf 1.6 -> 1.7, any use_parent_model_frame element with a true value is mapped to an //axis/xyz/@expressed_in attribute with value __model__, corresponding to the name of the model frame in the sdf frame semantics proposal.

It adds new API's to the sdf::JointAxis class and deprecates the API's related to use_parent_model_frame.

After some experimenting with xml stylesheets, I decided to include an xslt that is equivalent to the 1_6.convert file. It is provided for reference but is not used by libsdformat or tested by the built-in tests.

I also made some minor formatting adjustments to the migration guide.

values.description:
The last `true` in `findFile` tells it to use custom find file callbacks, which means we can use, for example, Fuel to find the file. The rest of the logic is making so we can get an SDF file from a directory containing `model.config`.

To try it out:

1. `ign gazebo -v 4 empty.sdf`


1. `ign service -s /world/empty/create --reqtype ignition.msgs.EntityFactory --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'sdf_filename: "https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/openrobotics/models/Double pendulum with base/"'`

This will be handy for the GUI to spawn Fuel models.

values.description: @{557057:f3a199b9-5784-4964-9644-6ef224bc7dc1} asked me why gcc-8 is required for compiling sdformat8, and I wasn't sure, so I tried testing in this branch by relaxing the cmake check and removing the gcc-8 installation from the pipeline in 020b9b5, and it still passed all the tests. So I'm inclined to relax the cmake check since it doesn't appear to be a strict requirement.

So I'm inclined to relax the cmake check since it doesn't appear to be a strict requirement.

The `_PKGCONFIG_*` variables are not being correctly exported in the cmake config file. This causes the following cmake warning in downstream packages (ign-physics in this case):

~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at /usr/share/cmake/ignition-cmake2/cmake2/IgnUtils.cmake:378 (message):
   -- THIS MESSAGE IS INTENDED FOR IGNITION-PHYSICS AUTHORS --
      (IF YOU SEE THIS, PLEASE REPORT IT)

  Could not find pkg-config information for sdformat8.  It was not provided
  by the find-module for the package, nor was it explicitly passed into the
  call to ign_find_package(~).  This is most likely an error in this
  project's use of ign-cmake.
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  CMakeLists.txt:59 (ign_find_package)
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.
~~~

This can be worked around in the downstream packages, but this should fix it in a cleaner way. This bug is causing the ignition-sensors3 homebrew bottle build to fail, so I've bumped the version to 8.6.0~pre1 and will make a prerelease.

values.description:
The sdf Converter uses the `*.convert` documents with `<convert>` tags and `name` attributes that specify the name of an element in the sdf hierarchy. This sometimes means that you have to duplicate the conversion code for elements that can appear in multiple locations, like models that can be in a world or directly under the `<sdf>` tag. This PR adds a `descendant_name` attribute that causes the converter to recurse through child elements to find matching tags. I've added a unit test but also modified the `1_6.convert` file to reduce code duplication, since these conversions have tests added in pull request #589.

The motivation for this change is the upcoming migration of the `//pose/@frame` attribute to `//pose/@relative_to`, which would be mind-boggingly painful to write out explicitly. I suppose it's also worth mentioning that none of our conversion code handles nested models, so this can make things more correct.
values.title: [Citadel] Converter: add `descendant_name` attribute to recursively search for elements to convert

values.description:
This builds on pull request #596 and implements part of the [proposal for sdformat 1.7](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#6-details-of-pose-relative_to-attribute) that renames the `//pose/@frame` attribute to `//pose/@relative_to`. The `descendant_name` attribute greatly simplifies the conversion specification in `1_6.convert`. I've added a test in `INTEGRATION_converter` to confirm the conversion is working and updated the parser and other tests where necessary.

The `PoseFrame()` DOM API's currently return the value of the `@relative_to` attribute, but these API's will be changed in subsequent pull requests.
values.title: [Citadel] sdf 1.7: rename `//pose/@frame` attribute to `//pose/@relative_to`

values.description: This is similar to pull request #598 and deprecates the `Pose()` and `SetPose()` DOM API's and replaces with `RawPose()` and `SetRawPose()` to give users more visibility to fact that they will need to call different API's to resolve poses against the user-defined graphs used in sdf 1.7.
values.title: [Citadel] Deprecate Pose() and SetPose() DOM API's in favor of RawPose and SetRawPose

values.description:
There are some new naming rules in the sdformat 1.7 proposal related to reserved names and unique names for sibling elements:

* http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#3-2-unique-names-for-all-sibling-elements
* http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#3-3-reserved-names

This PR checks for reserved names when loading DOM objects and checks for sibling name uniqueness with `ign sdf --check`. It includes several sdf files and tests.

I've targeted pull request #589 directly, since it is independent of the other chain of pull requests changing the API for accessing and resolving poses, so this can be reviewed independently.
values.title: [Citadel] Enforce rules about reserved names and unique names among sibling elements
